newsitem.title: USA: FORECAST-Sterling/dollar to fade in months ahead.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-Sterling/dollar to fade in months ahead.

text.p: The British pound will soon surrender some of its recent sharp gains versus the dollar, according to analysts polled by Reuters.
Despite pushing to a one-year high near $1.59 Wednesday, the pound is due for a modest pullback, which should steadily take the unit toward $1.54 by early next year, the poll shows.
The mean forecast of 15 analysts surveyed shows the sterling/dollar rate easing to $1.5576 in the fourth quarter of 1996 and $1.5402 in the second quarter of 1997.
The pound has rallied fiercely in recent sessions, primarily against European currencies, which has helped fuel heavy buying of sterling for dollars.

A relatively healthy U.K. economy offers the prospect of higher interest rates there, while the U.K.'s refusal to join a proposed single European currency has prompted jittery investors to switch funds to the pound, analysts noted.
But many foreign exchange professionals expect the current euphoria to fade as the rest of Europe's economies begin to recover.
Many also noted that the dollar should eventually recover from recent sterling/dollar buying, which they deemed mostly technical.
The poll yielded wide-ranging forecasts, with analysts seeing the pound as high as $1.75 and as low as $1.41 through the end of 1997.
